snippet: It took more than an hour for firefighters to arrive at Baghdad’s Yarmouk hospital. No one could find keys to the nursery. None of the fire extinguishers worked....
abstract: Nursery fire in one of Baghdad's main hospitals results in deaths of at least 13 infants, with at least 25 more people, mostly infants, being treated for burns or smoke inhalation; tragedy is painful reminder of dismal state of Iraqi infrastructure and services, as it would have been entirely preventable if hospital staff had been able to find keys to unlock nursery and if fire extinguishers were operational.

byline.original: By FALIH HASSAN, OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO
byline.contributor: Falih Hassan and Omar Al-Jawoshy reported from Baghdad, and Tim Arango from Istanbul.

lead_paragraph: It took more than an hour for firefighters to arrive at Baghdad’s Yarmouk hospital. No one could find keys to the nursery. None of the fire extinguishers worked.

headline.main: ‘A Fire Happened in the Newborn Unit, and Your Baby Died’
headline.print_headline: In Broken Iraq, a Nursery Fire Kills 13 Infants
